required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Dental Rehabilitation of Cancer Patients With Bone Metastases on High Dose Antiresorptives
clinical_study.official_title: Dental Rehabilitation of Cancer Patients With Bone Metastases on High Dose Antiresorptives

brief_summary.textblock: Aim of the study is to examine the feasibility of dental implant insertion in a pilot project in patients on high dose antiresorptive treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: This project includes 30 patients with bone metastases on high dose antiresorptive treatment (HDAR) for the prevention of bone complications. Definition of HDAR refers to the antiresorptive dose used per label in cancer patients with bone metastases to prevent bone complications.

primary_outcome.description: Defined as presence of the implant in the jaw after initial implant surgery before abutment surgery
Defined as presence of the implant at time of final prosthetics
Defined as presence of the implant 1 year after loading of the final prosthetics
Defined as presence of the implant 2 years after loading of the final prosthetics
Defined as less marginal bone loss than 1.5 mm the first year, and 0.2 mm per year thereafter at time of assessment

primary_outcome.measure: Absence of medical related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ)
primary_outcome.description: Defined as no exposed bone, no fistula, no radiologic sign of MRONJ

secondary_outcome.description: Using OHIP-49 questionnaire to evaluate oral health-related quality of life
Performance of the EORTC questionnaire for the assessment of quality of life in head and neck cancer patients

arm_group.description: Cancer patients (breast, prostate or multiple myeloma) with bone metastases on high dose antiresorptive treatment who have had previous tooth extraction

Cancer patients (breast, prostate or multiple myeloma) with bone metastases on high dose antiresorptive treatment who have lost teeth due to having previous osteonecrosis of the jaw which has been successfully surgically treated and healed for at least 3 months without recurrence

Cancer patients (breast, prostate or multiple myeloma) with ongoing osteonecrosis of the jaw to be surgically treated with block resection of the lower jaw and insertion of a titanium reconstruction plate. Simultaneous insertion of dental implants, or resection of the upper jaw where there is sufficient remaining bone volume to have implants inserted simultaneously (without bone augmentation)

intervention.description: Dental surgery in cancer patients in high dose antiresorptive treatment
Prosthetic treatment and loading of the dental implants

study_pop.textblock: Total or partial toothless cancer patients, treated at Copenhagen University Hospital due to treatment with high dose antiresorptive treatment. The patients had former tooth extractions or resections of the jaw at our clinic.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Cancer patients (breast, prostate or multiple myeloma) with bone metastases on high dose antiresorptive treatment (HDAR) for the prevention of bone complications. We will include all three cancer types (breast cancer, prostate and multiple myeloma) in the order they are enrolled.
- The patients should have sufficient compliance, this includes willingness to have the planned assessments, eg. EORTC QLQ-H&N 35.
- The patient should have an ECOG score (Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group) â‰¤ 2.
- Each patient should have a recent (within 3 months) cancer stage and prognosis assessment by the responsible oncologist before the start of implant treatment.
- The patient should have an expected life span at enrollment of at least 2 years.
- The local bone quality and quantity should be sufficient for implant insertion without bone augmentation and is classified according to the classification by Cawood & Howell 1988.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Tobacco smoking
- Diabetes
- Poor oral hygiene
- Poor general condition: ECOG score 3 or 4.
- Poor prognosis: Expected survival <2 year is an exclusion cause.
- Cancer assessment is defined by the oncologist.
- Presence of metastases of the liver brain.
- Poor local jaw bone quality acc. to Cawood classification stage 3 or 4.
- Unwillingness to comply with the planned assessments and recordings
- The patient must not be enrolled in the Amgen supported study: ONJ Registry Study, Protocol 2010 1102

responsible_party.investigator_title: Resident in Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
